I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
India  for  the  Odisha  Skill  Development  Project. 1  The  report  also  describes  proposed 
administration  of  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  be  provided  by  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty 
Reduction  for  Capacity  Building  for  the  Odisha  Skill  Development  Project,  and  if  the  Board 
approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, approve 
the TA. 
 
2. 
The project will help the Government of Odisha train about 200,000 youth aged 15–34 to 
increase their skills, employability, and income. The project aims to train new entrants and existing 
workers  in  priority  sectors  such  as  manufacturing,  construction,  and  services  for  formal 
employment. The project will benefit youth, women, and disadvantaged groups.2 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Odisha’s economy is in transition, with the industry and services sectors having emerged 
as the main drivers of growth. Between 1996 and 2015, agriculture’s share of gross state domestic 
product declined from 32% to 15%, industry’s share almost doubled from 18% to 33%, and the 
contribution  of  services  stayed  at  around  51%.  Odisha  also  achieved  the  largest  reduction  in 
poverty  (by  25  percentage  points)  among  India’s  major  states  between  2005  and  2013.3  Yet 
Odisha’s  poverty  rate  at  33%  remains  one  of  the  highest  in  India.  Despite  economic 
transformation, half of the working population continues to be employed in agriculture, while one-
quarter are employed in industry and another quarter in services. Nearly 80% of the employed 
are in the informal sector. The main challenge for Odisha’s economy lies in moving its labor force 
from the less productive agriculture and the informal sector to the more productive formal sector 
where wages are higher.4  
 
4. 
A  core  problem  in  Odisha  is  the  low  employability  of  its  young  workforce  in  the  formal 
sector due to their low skill levels. Youth aged 15–34 make up one-third of Odisha’s population of 
42 million. While the youth unemployment rate (6.8%) is slightly higher than the national average 
(5.8%), their underemployment rate (11.0%) is nearly double the national average (6.0%).5 Only 
a very small proportion of the youth has had any formal vocational training (1.8%, compared to 
the national average of 3.7%), and their education level is below the national average.6 Women 
are  even  less  likely  than  men  to  be  educated  or  have  any  formal  vocational  training,  and  a 
significant gender gap exists in labor force participation (29% for women and 80% for men aged 
15–34).  
 
5. 

Under the national “Make in India” and “Skill India” campaigns, the Government of India 

                                                
1   The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2   The Asian Development Bank (ADB) provided a project preparatory TA. 
3   Government of Odisha. 2015. Odisha Economic Survey, 2014–2015. Bhubaneswar.  
4   National Commission for Enterprises in the Unorganized Sector. 2009. The Challenge of Employment in India: An 

5   ADB staff estimates using data from the Government of India, Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation. 

Informal Economy Perspective. New Delhi. 

National Sample Survey, 2011–2012. New Delhi. 

6  In Odisha, the percentage of youth with education up to grade 10 is 25% compared to 32% nationwide; and the 

percentage of those with a diploma or higher degree is 7% compared to 11% nationwide.  

 

 2 

 

emphasizes building the skills of the youth to obtain high-quality jobs and higher wages in the 
manufacturing  and  services  sectors.  Yet,  states  like  Odisha,  which  have  large  tribal  and 
disadvantaged populations and large young workforce, face significant challenges in equipping 
their  populations  with  skills  to  meet  labor  market  needs.  According  to  a  skills-gap  study 
commissioned for Odisha by the National Skill Development Corporation, demand for semiskilled 
and  skilled  workers  will  continue  to  increase.7 The  cumulative  demand–supply  gap  for  skilled 
workers during 2011–2026 is estimated to be about 4 million, with high demand in the sectors 
such as construction, manufacturing, transportation and logistics, information technology (IT) and 
IT-enabled  services,  education  and  financial  services,  and  health  care.  Since  Odisha  is  a  net 
exporter of workers to other parts of India and abroad, the demand for skilled workers will likely 
be even greater.  
 
Odisha aimed to train 1 million people by the end of India’s Twelfth Five-Year Plan, 2012–
6. 
2017. It further aims to train additional 800,000 people by 2019. However, the capacity and quality 
of existing training programs are far from adequate to meet this target. The state has trained only 
about  330,000  people  during 2014–2015. To  cope  with  skilling  demand,  the  state government 
has introduced several initiatives. It established a high-level Odisha State Employment Mission 
(OSEM) in 2005–2006 to address the problems of youth unemployment and underemployment. 
It also established the Skill Development and Technical Education Department (SDTED) in 2015 
to  improve  coordination  among  different  government  agencies  responsible  for  skills  training, 
employment generation services, and labor regulation.8 Yet, the state government’s investment 
in skills training such as in industrial training institutes (ITIs) under the Directorate of Technical 
Education  and  Training  (DTET)  has  not  responded  adequately  to  industry  needs  due  to  poor 
training infrastructure and outdated skills standards, assessment, and certification processes.  
 
7. 
Odisha’s  current  skills  development  system  faces  numerous  constraints:  (i)  training 
capacity  is  insufficient  to  meet  the  5-year  plan  target,  and  the  geographic  spread  of  training 
institutions  is  uneven;  (ii)  the  quality  and  relevance  of  training  is  inadequate  due  to  outdated 
curricula and equipment, and a shortage of industry-experienced trainers, especially at ITIs; (iii) 
a  robust  quality  assurance  system  is  lacking  to  benchmark  training  institutions  to  international 
standards; (iv) employer linkages of training programs are weak; (v) limited autonomy in public 
institutions  constrains  market-responsive  training;  (vi)  the  skills  ecosystem  is  fragmented  with 
weak  institutional  coordination;  (vii)  mentoring  institutions  to  transform  ITIs  into  more  effective 
institutions  are  absent;  and  (viii)  viable  training  models  are  in  need  to  deliver  advanced  skills 
programs, particularly for  higher-cost, capital-intensive manufacturing.  
 
To address these constraints in skills development, the state government established an 
8. 
autonomous implementation institution in 2016, the Odisha Skill Development Authority (OSDA), 
headed by an eminent industry leader.9 OSDA brings together all skills training programs of the 
state under one strong coordinating entity to streamline existing institutional arrangements. OSDA 
aims to achieve the state’s skills targets by implementing high-quality, market-responsive training 
programs in line with the state development strategies in priority sectors such as manufacturing, 
construction,  and  services  (e.g.,  automotive  and  health  care).  To  this  end,  OSDA  has  three 
priorities: (i) to enhance the ITIs’ capacity; (ii) to accelerate training capacity by introducing eight 
new  advanced  skills  training  institutes  (ASTIs);  and  (iii)  to  scale  up  short-term,  employment-
                                                
7   Ernst & Young. 2012. Skill Gap Assessment for the State of Odisha: A District Wise Analysis. Kolkata. 
8   The state government established the Employment, Technical Education, and Training Department in 2012, which 

was renamed the SDTED in 2015. 

9   OSDA  succeeds  the  previous  Odisha  Skill  Development  Society,  created  in  2015,  by  merging  with  OSEM.  This 
merger created a more consolidated institution to coordinate and implement skills development initiatives in Odisha.  

 

 

 3 

related training through private training providers.  
      
9. 
The proposed project will help the Government of Odisha transform its skills development 
system by establishing eight new ASTIs and invigorating government ITIs under a hub-and-spoke 
model.10 The  proposed  model  aims  to  expand  the  state’s  training  capacity,  uplift  the  quality  of 
skills training, and strengthen the market relevance of training programs, which would enhance 
the skills and employability of young workforce for the high-demand priority sectors. The project 
design incorporates emerging national and international good practices and lessons learned.11 
The following are specific innovative features of the project:   
 

(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

A hub-and-spoke model. The project will establish a network of eight ASTIs as 
hubs and 30 government ITIs as spokes. Each hub will serve as a resource center 
for a group of ITIs by mentoring in pedagogy, technology use, industry linkages, 
training of trainers, recognition of prior learning (RPL), and other areas. Each hub 
and spoke will form a cluster that specializes in skills for a specific priority sector 
aligned with labor market demands in Odisha, other parts of India, and overseas. 
The  strategic  spread  of  the  hubs  in  eight  different  locations  across  Odisha  will 
provide  more  equitable  access  to  high-quality  training  by  diverse  groups.  The 
model will leverage project resources to introduce operational efficiency from the 
private  sector,  uplift  the  quality  of  overall  skills  training,  and  complement  other 
initiatives in meeting the state’s training targets.  
 
Private  sector  engagement.  OSDA  will  engage  experienced  private  training 
institutions  to  operate  and  maintain  the  ASTIs  in  partnership  with  international 
partners  and  strengthen  the  market  relevance  of  training  programs.  This 
arrangement  will  support  the  “Make  in  India”  and  “Skill  India”  campaigns,  by 
incentivizing private operators to develop sustainable quality training models and 
scale  up  skills  for  job  opportunities  in  manufacturing  and  services  within  and 
outside Odisha. OSDA will also set up an industrial advisory committee consisting 
of  one  representative  from  each  priority  sector  to  facilitate  on-the-job  training, 
upskilling of existing workers, and employer linkages, while mobilizing resources 
from corporate social responsibility to ensure sustainability.  

Convergence with national policies and priorities. The project is aligned with 
the National Policy for Skill Development and Entrepreneurship 2015,  which the 
Ministry of Skill Development and Entrepreneurship approved in July 2015. This 
alignment  ensures  that  training  courses  comply  with  the  requirements  of  the 
National  Skills  Qualification  Framework.  It  also  ensures  that  a  robust  quality 
assurance  system  is  in place  by  (a)  applying  emerging  standards  set  by  sector 
skills councils and the National Skill Development Agency, (b) enhancing capacity 
to  train  trainers  and  assessors,  (c)  benchmarking  ASTIs  and  ITIs,  and  (d) 
institutionalizing a credible assessment and certification system.  

  
The  project  reflects  the  priorities  of  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  in  its  country 
10. 
partnership  strategy,  2013–2017  for  India,  which  reinforces  India’s  efforts  to  achieve  inclusive 
growth and recognizes education, especially vocational training, as a new sector in ADB’s India 

                                                
10  No ASTI currently exists; all eight ASTIs are to be established under the project.  
11  Lessons Learned (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
 

 

 

 4 

 

Outputs 

Impact and Outcome 

operation.12 The project is aligned with the Midterm Review of Strategy 2020, which emphasizes 
ADB’s need to expand lending for post-basic education and vocational training to develop human 
capital,  and  facilitate  public–private  partnerships  to  leverage  results.13 Odisha  will  be  the  third 
state to receive ADB support for skills development, after the states of Meghalaya and Kerala.14  
  
B. 
 
11. 
The  impact  will  be  reduced  unemployment  and  underemployment  rates  for  female  and 
male youth (aged 15–34) by 2025. The outcome will be increased skills and employment in the 
priority sectors for the working-age population.     
 
C. 
 
12. 
Output  1:  Equitable  access  to  market-responsive  skills  development  programs 
increased. This output will support a network of eight new ASTIs as hubs and 30 government 
ITIs as spokes under a hub-and-spoke model that will train about 195,000 people, of which about 
120,000 will be trained by ASTIs; 50,000 by ITIs; and 25,000 through RPL. Two ASTI models will 
be  supported.  For  six  ASTIs,  OSDA  will  provide  land,  new  buildings,  and  equipment,  and  will 
engage public or private training providers to operate and maintain the ASTIs. For the other two 
ASTIs, OSDA will provide equipment, while public or private training providers will provide land 
and  buildings  to  optimize  the  use  of  existing  facilities.  This  output  has  four  sub-outputs:  (i) 
increased access to quality training through a hub-and-spoke model, with the provision of new 
buildings  and  laboratory  equipment  for  eight  ASTIs,15 and  hostels,  workshops,  and  laboratory 
equipment  for  30  ITIs;16 (ii)  improved  access  to  training  for  women  and  disadvantaged  social 
groups;  (iii)  market-responsive  training  programs  delivered  for  the  state’s  priority  sectors  in 
collaboration with key industry players; and (iv) RPL systems established. 
 
13. 
Output  2:  Quality  and  relevance  of  skills  development  programs  improved.  This 
output  focuses  on  ensuring  the  quality  of  training  programs  by  supporting  the  following  sub-
outputs: (i) a robust quality assurance system established to ensure that training programs meet 
acceptable standards and apply credible assessment and certification procedures; (ii) a pool of 
about 250 master trainers created and a mechanism developed to train about 14,000 trainers, 
including about 1,000 assessors; (iii) eight ASTIs and 30 ITIs benchmarked against a set of key 
performance  indicators  to  be  identified;  and  (iv)  technology-enabled  training  and  learning 
programs promoted. 
 
Output 3: Skills ecosystem strengthened. In line with the national priority to consolidate 
14. 
and  strengthen  training  programs  within  a  common  framework  at  the  state  level,  this  output 
comprises the following sub-outputs: (i) partnerships with international and national knowledge 
institutions and other government departments promoted; (ii) career counseling and placement 
centers established in each of the eight ASTIs and 30 ITIs; (iii) self-employment initiatives piloted 
to train 5,000 people to demonstrate viable replication and scaling up schemes; and (iv) a skill 
database and inventory developed to help recruit appropriate candidates and to link trainees with 
                                                
12  ADB. 2013. Country Partnership Strategy: India, 2013–2017. Manila.   
13  ADB. 2014. Midterm Review of Strategy 2020: Meeting the Challenges of a Transforming Asia and Pacific. Manila. 
14   ADB.  2013.  Report  and  Recommendation  of  the  President  to  the  Board  of  Directors:  Proposed  Loan  and 
Administration of  Technical  Assistance  Grant  to  India for  Supporting  Human  Capital  Development  in  Meghalaya. 
Manila;  ADB.  2014.  Report  and  Recommendation  of  the  President  to  the  Board  of  Directors:  Proposed  Results-
Based  Loan  and  Administration  of  Technical  Assistance  Grant  to  India  for  Supporting  Kerala’s  Additional  Skill 
Acquisition Program in Post-Basic Education. Manila. 

15   The ADB loan will finance civil works for six ASTIs and equipment for all eight ASTIs. 
16 The government will finance hostels, workshops, and laboratory equipment for the ITIs. 

 

 5 

potential employers before training begins. 
 
15. 
Output  4:  Institutional  capacity  strengthened.  This  output  aims  to  strengthen  the 
capacity  of  institutions,  including  the  SDTED,  OSDA,  DTET,  and  ITIs,  to  ensure  the  effective 
implementation of planned activities. There are four sub-outputs: (i) financial and administrative 
autonomy of OSDA strengthened; (ii) public or private operators engaged to manage and operate 
the ASTIs under OSDA supervision; (iii) a robust and unified monitoring and evaluation system 
institutionalized; and (iv) a project management consultant (PMC) team engaged to strengthen 
ITI leadership and to support OSDA, SDTED, and DTET.  
 
D. 
 
The project is estimated to cost $162 million, including taxes, duties, interests, and other 
16. 
charges  (Table  1).  Detailed  cost  estimates  are  included  in  the  project  administration  manual 
(PAM).17 

Investment and Financing Plans

Source: ADB estimates. 
 
17. 
The Government of India has requested a regular loan of $102 million from ADB’s ordinary 
capital resources to help finance the project.18 The loan will have a 20-year term, including a grace 
period of 5 years, an annual interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank 
offered rate-based lending facility, a commitment charge of 0.15% per year, straight-line payment, 
and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan and project agreements. Based on 
the  straight-line  payment  method,  the  average  loan  maturity  is  12.75  years,  and  there  is  no 
maturity premium payable to ADB. 
 
18. 
 
                                                
17   Project Administration Manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

partnership strategy preparation; (ii) do not represent an excessive share of the investment plan (7.8% of the loan); 
(iii) apply only to ADB-financed expenditures; and (iv) are considered relevant to the project’s success. 

The financing plan is in Table 2. The ADB loan will finance 63% of the project cost.

Implementation Arrangements 

  
E. 
 
19. 
The  SDTED  will  be  the  executing  agency  for  the  project.  OSDA,  created  by  the  state 
government  with  financial  and  administrative  autonomy,  will  be  the  implementing  agency.  A 
project steering committee (PSC) has been formed, consisting of OSDA’s chairman (president), 
the secretary of the SDTED (vice-president), director of the DTET (member), and chief executive 
officer (CEO) of the project management unit (PMU) (member convener). The PSC will provide 
oversight  of  project  implementation,  approving  its  annual  work  plans  and  budget,  reviewing 
training progress, assessing implementation constraints, and facilitating synergy across relevant 
government and private sector institutions. The PMU will be under OSDA, headed by a CEO and 
a  management  team  consisting  of  experts  on  vocational  training,  industry  relations,  quality 
assurance,  financial  management,  and  procurement.  The  PMU  experts  will  be  recruited 
competitively  with  market-based  remuneration.  The  CEO  will  act  as  the  project  director,  as 
delegated  by  the  SDTED.  The  implementation  arrangements  are  summarized  in  Table  3  and 
described in detail in the PAM (footnote 17).

Upon request, ADB may allow advance contracting and retroactive financing of 
civil works, equipment, and consulting services in accordance with ADB 
policies and procedures. Retroactive financing will be up to 20% of the ADB 
loan amount for eligible expenditures of civil works, equipment, and consulting 
services incurred prior to loan effectiveness but not earlier than 12 months 
prior to the signing of the loan agreement. 
The loan proceeds will be disbursed in accordance with ADB's Loan 
Disbursement Handbook (2015, as amended from time to time) and detailed 
arrangements agreed between the Government of Odisha and ADB. 

ADB  =  Asian  Development  Bank,  DTET  =  Directorate  of  Technical  Education  and  Training,  OSDA  =  Odisha  Skill 
Development  Authority,  PMU  =  project  management  unit,  PSC  =  project  steering  committee,  SDTED  =  Skill 
Development and Technical Education Department, TBD = to be determined.   
Source: ADB estimates.    

 
 

 

 7 

III. 

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

 
20. 
The  attached capacity  development  TA  is  estimated  to  cost  $2.4  million,  of  which $2.0 
million  will  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  and 
administered by ADB. The TA has been designed to strengthen the capacity of OSDA during the 
first 2 years of implementation and ensure that start-up activities are implemented effectively. The 
TA  will  help  OSDA  build  its  capacity  in  identifying  specific  skills  needs,  introducing  short-term 
training  responsive  to  market  needs,  and  establishing  market  linkages  with  industries.  The 
SDTED  is  the  executing  agency.  The  state government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in the 
form of counterpart staff, office accommodation and supplies, and other in-kind contributions.19 
The TA will be implemented from July 2017 to June 2019.  
 

IV. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Technical 

 
A. 
 
The  design  and  cost  estimates  are  based  on  inputs  from  a  wide  range  of  experts  and 
21. 
practitioners.  Priority  sectors  and  trades  were  selected  based  on  skills-gap  analysis,  demand 
estimation linked to manufacturing and services sector needs, feedback from ITI principals, and 
discussions with industry experts and training sector practitioners. The demand for skills is linked 
to state, national, and overseas labor markets. The design combines leveraging investments from 
the government, private sector, users, and employers, along with the private sector’s efficiency to 
deliver training services effectively. 
 
Economic and Financial 
B. 
 
 
22. 
Economic  viability.  The  project’s  economic  viability  was  assessed  based  on  the 
associated benefits and costs. Economic benefits include (i) direct benefits for students, including 
increased employability and higher wages; (ii) direct benefits for employers in terms of improved 
productivity  and  returns  on  investment;  and  (iii)  improved  internal  efficiency  through  reduced 
system wastage caused by lower completion rates. The three major streams of economic costs 
are (i) direct project costs associated with the four outputs; (ii) private costs of trainee fees, and 
indirect  opportunity  costs  of foregone  earnings during  training;  and (iii)  costs  borne  by  various 
training schemes. The project is estimated to yield a net present value of $181.4 million under the 
base scenario, with an economic internal rate of return (EIRR) of 21.6%. The EIRR was tested 
for sensitivity to four different scenarios: (i) a 10% capital cost overrun (EIRR 18.2%), (ii) a 10% 
recurrent cost overrun (EIRR 19.4%), (iii) a 10% lower wage increase (EIRR 17.8%), and (iv) a 
combination of (i) and (iii) (EIRR 14.6%). In all cases, the EIRR exceeds the required rate of 9%, 
suggesting that the project is economically robust. 
 
Fiscal  sustainability.  The  incremental  recurrent  costs  after  project  completion  are 
23. 
estimated at ₹580 million per year at constant prices; these costs include maintaining buildings 
and equipment, retaining and retraining ITI instructors, and retaining core staff. This represents 
only 4.2% of Odisha’s total estimated budget for technical and vocational education and training 
in  FY2023,  which  the  state  government  is  committed  to  support.  The  project’s  long-term 
sustainability will depend on (i) increasing the quality of skills training to meet satisfactory labor 
market outcomes; (ii) ensuring a coordinated approach to skills development to optimize various 
training  schemes  and  to  support  trainees  who  are  less  able  to  afford  the  training  costs;  (iii) 
increasing  labor force  productivity,  leading  to  higher  returns  on  business investments;  and (iv) 

                                                
19  Attached Technical Assistance (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

 

 8 

 

Governance 

gradually  increasing  wages  to  induce  more  individual  investment  in  skills  training.  The  project 
proposes to address these critical areas.  
 
C. 
 
24. 
Detailed  assessments  of financial  management, procurement,  and governance  policies 
and  procedures  of  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  show  that  the  overall  project 
fiduciary risk is substantial. As India has robust public financial management systems, and strong 
procurement, governance, anticorruption arrangements, and monitoring institutions, these risks 
emanate primarily from OSDA, whose policies, systems, and procedures are newly established 
(footnote  12).  The  state-level  procurement  capacity  assessment  showed  that  procurement 
policies and procedures are in place and in line with the Odisha General Financial Rules, such as 
the  Guidelines  for  Procurement  of  Goods  (2012)  and  the  Works  Department’s  procedural 
requirements  on  the  procurement  of  works,  including  the  Codal  Provisions  Regarding  e-
Procurement  (2013).  At  the  sector  level,  the  executing  agency,  the  SDTED,  has  no  specific 
procurement unit. The financial management and procurement capacity assessments identified 
the following key risks: (i) weak financial management capacity of SDTED and OSDA, (ii) absence 
of an internal audit function at SDTED, (iii) low fund utilization at DTET and the former OSEM, 
and (iv) absence of an IT-based accounting system.  
 
To overcome these weaknesses, OSDA as the implementing agency will have a highly 
25. 
experienced and qualified PMU team headed by a dynamic CEO. OSDA will engage a PMC team 
to support its operations. The financial management action plan proposes key measures such as 
adequate and qualified staffing, centralized procurement by OSDA with support from an expert 
team, clear funds-flow directed through SDTED to OSDA, and installation of IT-based accounting 
systems for recording and reporting. In addition, an internal audit team familiar with government 
accounting methods will be engaged to enhance fiduciary controls over OSDA activities. ADB’s 
Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  was  explained  to  and  discussed  with  the 
Government  of  India,  Government  of  Odisha,  and  SDTED.  Specific  policy  requirements  and 
supplementary measures are described in the PAM (footnote 17).  

 
Poverty and Social 

D. 
 
26. 
Between  2005  and  2013,  Odisha  recorded  the  largest  reduction  in  poverty  (by  25 
percentage points) among all major states in India. Yet Odisha’s poverty rate at 33% remains the 
second  highest  in  the  country.  Odisha  also  has  India’s  third  highest  proportion  of  scheduled 
castes  and  tribal  people,  who  constitute  almost  half  of  the  state’s  poor.  Significant  gender 
differences exist in labor force participation among those aged 15–34 (80% for men and 29% for 
women); and in the literacy rate (82% for men and 64% for women) (footnote 5). The literacy rate 
is  also  much  lower  for  women  from  scheduled  castes  and  scheduled  tribes.  The  project  is 
categorized as having a gender equity theme, since it aims to train about 200,000 youth, of whom 
25% will be women, 30% from disadvantaged groups, and 3% people with disabilities. To mobilize 
and ensure the active participation of the target groups, especially women, in training, the project 
will  implement  a  rigorous  social  marketing  and  communication  strategy.  The  project  will  also 
support career counseling and job placement services in all ASTIs and spoke ITIs to consider the 
special  needs  of  women  and  other  targeted  groups.  Fee  concessions,  subsidies,  and  hostel 
facilities will also be provided to motivate the target groups to participate in the training programs 
and to promote their employment.  
 
 
 

 

 9 

Safeguards 

E. 
 
27. 
The loan is categorized C for involuntary resettlement, as there will be no land acquisition 
or resettlement impacts. Six ASTIs and hostels in 30 ITIs will be constructed on land within the 
premises  of  existing  educational  institutions,  or  other  encumbrance-free  land  owned  by  the 
government. Project components or subprojects that would trigger the involuntary resettlement 
safeguards  of  ADB’s  Safeguard Policy  Statement  (2009)  are not  eligible for funding  under  the 
project. The loan is categorized B for indigenous peoples, as Odisha’s population is composed of 
23% scheduled tribes and 16% scheduled castes. An indigenous peoples plan has been prepared 
to ensure access to the project’s training programs for all indigenous peoples in the state. The 
loan is categorized B for environment, considering the scope of the civil works for six ASTIs and 
the  environmental  investigations  of  the  ASTI  project  sites.  An  environment  assessment  and 
review framework has been prepared for the still-unidentified sites of the remaining two ASTIs. 
The  initial  environmental  examination reports,  including  environmental management  plans  and 
environmental assessment and review framework, have been prepared and disclosed on the ADB 
website. The implementation status of environmental management plans will be reported to ADB 
semiannually.   
 
F. 
 
28.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail in 
the risk assessment and risk management plan.20 The assessment indicates that the overall risk 
is  moderate  to  substantial.  However,  the  integrated  benefits  and  impacts  are  expected  to 
outweigh the costs.  
 

Risks and Mitigating Measures 

Table 4: Summary of Key Risks and Mitigating Measures 

 

Risks 
Weak financial 
management and 
procurement capacity 
of the SDTED and 
newly established 
OSDA 
Motivation to 
undertake skills 
training among youth 
may be constrained 
due to uncertain job 
placement 
opportunities 
Limited interest from 
the private sector in 
ASTI operations may 
lead to an insufficient 
pool of eligible ASTI 
operators 

Mitigating Measures 
OSDA will have financial management and procurement specialists to support 
day-to-day financial management and procurement  activities for the  project. 
An internal audit function will also be established. The PMC team will support 
OSDA, SDTED, and DTET (for ITIs) in implementing the project. The JFPR 
capacity  building  TA  will  support  targeted  activities  to  enhance  financial 
management and procurement capacity. 
The project will support several measures including (i) involvement of the PMC 
team and training institutions in mobilization and recruitment efforts for target 
trainees; (ii) provision of market-relevant training based on demand analysis 
and mapping of job opportunities in industries; and (iii) engagement of a social 
marketing  firm  to  inform  target  trainees  about  jobs,  living  conditions,  and 
career  opportunities  (including 
through  career 
counseling and job placement support. 
The  SDTED  has  compiled  a  list  of  potential  operators  based  on  market 
analysis,  and  has  organized  business  opportunities  workshops.  OSDA  will 
reach out to experienced operators and create support mechanisms to attract 
them, including the creation of an industry advisory committee comprised of 
representatives from each priority sector to interface with industry and sector 
skills  councils;  and  cooperation  with  large  industry  groups  through  their 
corporate responsibility commitment.  

those  outside  Odisha) 

ASTI = advanced skills training institute, DTET = Directorate of Technical Education and Training,  ITI = industrial 
training institute, JFPR = Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, OSDA = Odisha Skill Development Authority, PMC = 
project management consultant, SDTED = Skill Development and Technical Education Department, TA = technical 
assistance.  
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
                                                
20  Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

 

 10 

 

V. 

ASSURANCES 

 
29. 
The Government  of India,  Government  of Odisha,  and  SDTED  have assured ADB  that 
implementation  of  the  project  shall  conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies  including  those 
concerning anticorruption measures, safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and 
disbursement as described in detail in the PAM and loan documents. 
 
30. 
certain covenants for the project, which are set forth in the loan and project agreements. 
 

The Government of India, Government of Odisha, and SDTED have agreed with ADB on 

VI. 

RECOMMENDATION 

 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
31. 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of 
$102,000,000  to  India  for  the  Odisha  Skill  Development  Project,  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
resources,  in  regular  terms,  with  interest  to  be  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  London 
interbank offered rate-based lending facility; for a term of 20 years, including a grace period of 5 
years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth 
in the draft loan and project agreements presented to the Board. 
 

Takehiko Nakao 
President 

 
 

 
 
30 May 2017
